Yorick Brown.Action: Uses a casual, somewhat humorous voiceover to introduce himself and the story, indicating a relaxed, informal confidence.
Nervously rambles and attempts to be charming during an interview despite lacking experience.
Refers to himself jokingly as 'more Elvis than Jesse' and 'a ninja with the grammar,' showing a self-deprecating humor and friendly tone.
Corrects the interviewer in a polite, informal way about his name preferences.
Admits honestly he hasn’t worked in over two years and explains his introspective period.
Asks if the interviewer was contacted by his mother, showing some surprise and openness.
Uses an offbeat, rambling monologue about Elvis and fate during a job interview, attempting humor and personality but lacking directness.
Acknowledges his lack of relevant work experience honestly when questioned by the interviewer.
Attempts to impress the interviewer with quirky references and self-deprecating humor instead of concrete qualifications.
Asks the interviewer if his mother had called her, revealing a lack of assertiveness in managing his own job prospects.
Greets his very pregnant neighbor and engages in friendly, supportive small talk, congratulating her on her baby boy.
Forces open the sticky front door despite it being difficult.
Shambles dejectedly towards his rundown brownstone, showing low energy and possibly low motivation.
Engages in polite conversation with his pregnant neighbor, demonstrating basic social skills and awareness.
Responds apologetically and somewhat sheepishly to landlord's complaint about smell.
Mumbles under his breath correcting the landlord's statement about pets allowed.
Speaks to his cat Ampersand with mild affection despite the pet's questionable hygiene.
Screams when startled by a dark figure unexpectedly.
Quickly gathers his bills and leaves the landlord's apartment without confrontation; tries to clarify the lease rules under his breath.
Screams when suddenly startled by a dark figure in his apartment.
Flips on the light switch quickly upon sensing something unexpected.
Engages in casual, slightly confused banter about personal relationships instead of immediately addressing potential danger.
Pulls Beth close, kisses her, shares a tender moment with playful banter.
Shows concern about safety during intimacy, questions Beth about protection.
Fumbles awkwardly with supplies when asked about protection, admits lack of preparedness.
Stops kissing abruptly upon learning Beth’s invented contraceptive is untested, showing panic.
Asks Beth questions about contraception and health indicating curiosity and engagement.
Appears uncertain and awkward in intimate situations, needing reassurance.
Expresses concern and reassurance to Beth about her health issue, showing care.
Makes a gentle, slightly humorous comment about Beth's previous tolerance to blood, indicating familiarity and attempt to lighten the mood.
Expresses understanding of Beth's condition and shows concern by confirming she is sure the treatment works.
Makes a light-hearted comment about Beth not minding the sight of blood, showing some social awareness but a casual tone.
Screams at his pet to stop biting Beth, apologizes sincerely.
Calmly tries to take the biting monkey from Beth and apologizes for its behavior.
Races to check on injured people in his apartment building and responds to cries for help outside despite uncertainty.
Is startled and nervous upon hearing the crash and muffled screams, showing initial hesitation.
Reluctantly leaves a woman to help others when hearing cries for help.
Shows concern and horror at the sight of dead men and chaos.
Interacts politely and gently with a young woman who crashed a garbage truck, showing concern for her well-being.
Avoids an accident by diving out of the way but continues onward with his task, showing determination rather than selfishness.
Reluctantly leaves a woman in distress to investigate cries for help, showing willingness to act amidst chaos.
Covers his mouth in horror when confronted by the carnage, indicating momentary shock but controlled physical reaction.
Uses emergency gear (gas mask and poncho) and carries an animal carrier, demonstrating preparedness and resourcefulness.
Quickly dives out of the way to avoid an out-of-control garbage truck, showing alertness and physical reflexes.
Communicates effectively despite muffled voice through gasmask, maintaining calm and interaction with others in a stressful environment.
Checks on the safety of his animal carrier's occupant before continuing.
Asks clarifying questions about the grim situation and tries to understand what the supermodel does with the corpses.
Tries not to vomit despite the disturbing scene, showing some emotional control.
Wears a mask out of caution even after being told it's unnecessary.
Pushes his way into a completely dark, unlit house at night, showing some assertiveness and boldness.
Successfully travels from New York to his mother's house despite challenging circumstances.
Replies calmly to his mother’s emotional outburst and confirms the reality of the situation.
Expresses frustration and helplessness after learning he might be the only survivor.
Punches a wall in anger and collapses, showing emotional breakdown.
Introduces Ampersand and openly shares his situation despite uncertainty.
Admits he hadn’t considered alternative possibilities about Ampersand.
Expresses feeling of being all alone without complaint or bitterness.
Expresses urgent desire to be with and help 'her' despite political concerns
Uses sarcastic and dismissive language toward government officials
Whispers encouragement to his father ('Come on, dad, a little help here...') when struggling to start the motorcycle.
Panics and hastily escapes Secret Service agents, prioritizing saving Ampersand and taking a photo of Beth.
Avoids confrontation by fleeing rather than engaging the agents, but still careful to protect those he cares about.
Quickly packs Ampersand, escapes through window before agents break in, finds and starts motorcycle despite initial panic.
Lands awkwardly and stumbles to feet after jumping from second story window.
Races out on motorcycle while carrying Ampersand's case, deftly outmaneuvers grasping agents.
Stops confidently at roadblock to catch breath and find bearings.
Approaches a masked figure with caution but tries to communicate, showing openness and trust by initiating conversation.
Responds to Heather’s handshake with a false name 'Beth', possibly to protect his identity.
Makes a light-hearted, mildly teasing comment about the Washington Monument to Heather.
Shows curiosity and concern upon seeing the armed women and their unusual behavior, engaging Heather in a direct question.
Mentions a rumor about the Daughters of the Amazon in a blunt, somewhat irreverent manner.
Shows concern for Ampersand after crashing his bike; groggily talks to him.
Attempts to outrun hostile pursuers rather than confront or negotiate.
Attempts to escape on his bike from two armed pursuers.
Fails to maintain control of the bike after being shot at, resulting in a crash.
Reluctantly removes gasmask despite discomfort under threat.
Attempts humor with terrible female impersonation voice to defuse tension.
Flinches in fear when gun is aimed at him but quickly secures Ampersand and responds to 355.
Refuses to immediately comply with Agent 355's order to hop on the motorcycle.
Matter-of-factly climbs onto 355's bike and says 'Right. And away we go.' after witnessing a devastating explosion.
Jokes lightly and attempts to engage Agent 355 in friendly banter, showing a desire to connect.
Expresses nervousness and relief about Agent 355's classified affiliation, revealing vulnerability and sincerity.
Responds to Agent 355 with casual humor and openness, admits ignorance about being the last man, and engages in conversation to gather information.
Questions Agent 355 about the Amazon movement's motives using logical reasoning, showing critical thinking.
Makes a flippant comment about his name and his father’s choice, showing a lack of seriousness in a dangerous situation.
Does not appear to take immediate steps to secure himself despite the clear danger noted by Agent 355.
Walks with Agent 355, openly shares his plans and feelings about Beth, indicating trust.
Expresses nervousness when discussing his priorities and plans, showing sincerity and vulnerability.
Casually steps behind Agent 355 when confronted by snarling wolves, allowing her to handle the threat efficiently.
Initially insists he can handle himself without a chaperone, showing confidence but possibly underestimating danger.
Appears boyishly enthusiastic and somewhat naive when faced with complex survival logistics (e.g., train travel arrangements).
Feeds most of his share of food to Ampersand (his pet).
Makes a crude joke about eating canned peaches and having a 'cobbler' last night.
Tries to keep light banter with Agent 355 despite their tense situation.
Dismisses Agent 355's irritation and makes a flippant comment about lighting towns, showing some insensitivity.
Offers to borrow a clean shirt from Agent 355 and acknowledges her help gratefully ('Third time you’ve saved my life, Three-fiddy.')
Jokes about having a stroke due to buttons being on the 'wrong' side, engages playfully with Agent 355
Corrects Agent 355 gently on cattle terminology, showing attentiveness and thoughtfulness in conversation
Tries to calm Ampersand, shows concern for others' safety.
Reluctantly prepares to use weapon on Agent 355, indicating willingness to harm an ally under duress.
Expresses concern about being left alone and needing Agent 355's help, showing dependency and trust.
Accepts the sawn-off shotgun from Agent 355 and prepares to attempt a dangerous mission to reach the conductor to disconnect the engine, despite feeling uncertain about making it alone.
Protests the plan and hesitates, expressing doubt in his ability to complete the mission without help.
Points the shotgun at Agent 355's head in a tense moment, indicating a lapse in judgment under stress.
Puts Ampersand (the monkey) into his backpack to quiet him, shows concern despite the frustration.
Calls Ampersand 'fucking learning disabled or something' in frustration.
Hides effectively on the roof of a moving freight train to evade pursuers.
Struggles to keep his pet monkey, Ampersand, quiet, showing limited control over situation.
Quickly stuffs Ampersand into his backpack to prevent detection, demonstrating quick thinking.
Jokes about the monkey's inability to be quiet, indicating some self-awareness but also a lack of serious control.
Appears grateful when Agent 355 steps in front of him to protect him, showing some trust and appreciation.
Tries to load his shotgun in a careless, trigger-happy way resulting in losing control of the weapon, indicating impulsiveness but not directly reflecting warmth.
Does not take aggressive action or retaliate when Victoria threatens him, showing some passivity and confusion but not hostility.
Attempts to load a shell into his sawed-off shotgun by flipping it Terminator 2-style but ends up dropping the weapon off the train.
Remains calm and grateful when Agent 355 protects him, showing trust and reliance on capable allies.
Exposed and confused after Agent 355 steps aside and Victoria aims her gun at him; no clear decisive action in response.
Goes along with being yanked off the moving train with Agent 355, indicating adaptability and survival instinct under extreme circumstances.
Notices Ampersand playing with his ring box and feels guilty, quickly snatches it away.
Joins Sonia at the window to look at the sixty-seven women gathered outside and sighs, showing reluctant acceptance of his situation.
Acknowledges his unique position as the sole surviving man and consciously tries not to take advantage of the situation, showing some self-restraint and awareness.
Wrestles with temptation and tries to maintain loyalty to his girlfriend Beth despite the difficult circumstances, indicating moral awareness but possible internal conflict reducing decisiveness.
Pulled away physically and verbally from Sonia's advances, but ultimately appears uncertain and uncomfortable, showing some lack of confidence in managing interpersonal boundaries.
Responds calmly to a tense situation with militia women and tries to understand the circumstances instead of reacting aggressively.
Dismisses the urgency of leaving immediately, showing a somewhat carefree or naive attitude toward danger.
Tries to play peacemaker when Agent 355 starts to lose her cool, attempting to diffuse tension between women and himself
Makes a lighthearted comment about being called 'boy' despite being a college graduate, showing a friendly attempt to lighten the mood
Plays peacemaker when Agent 355 starts to lose her cool, attempts to de-escalate tension by suggesting everyone pretend the encounter never happened.
Questions why people keep calling him 'boy,' showing some confusion about how others perceive him.
Appears baffled by the sudden arrival of hostile helicopters and the setup, indicating he is caught off-guard and perhaps unprepared.

Screams in fear and revulsion at the killing of the soldiers, vomits after witnessing the violence, questions Agent 355 about the morality of killing rather than wounding, expresses disgust and a desire to withdraw from violent actions.
Gives up fighting and says he will surrender to prevent more deaths.

Engages in light-hearted, friendly conversation with Agent 355, showing curiosity about her background.

Remains silent and nervous when flying in a dangerous situation, but does not show hostility or negativity.
Silently stares out the window nervously during a risky helicopter flight.
Acknowledges opening the door to conflict after being threatened, showing self-awareness.
Expresses disbelief about Agent 355’s piloting skills but engages in conversation, showing a willingness to learn.
Quietly speaks to his frightened monkey, acknowledges both their vulnerabilities with a light comment about needing a diaper change.
Quietly acknowledges the need to change his monkey's diaper and shows awareness of his situation.
Questions their navigation and the likelihood of reaching their target, showing engagement with the mission.
Expresses concern about potential delays and competitors, indicating situational awareness and strategic thinking.
Acknowledges gender issues and expresses support for women (e.g., down with the cause, rarely makes sexist jokes, holds doors open).
Engages in playful banter and light teasing with Agent 355, maintaining a friendly, humorous interaction.
Waves off self-defense lessons confidently, implying self-reliance.
Calmly watches the burning Vegas skyline while the helicopter refuels, showing composure in crisis.
Admits he rarely makes sexist jokes and holds doors open, indicating some social awareness and thoughtfulness.
Waves off Agent 355's offer to teach him self-defense, asserting he has gotten out of scrapes before, showing confidence but potential overestimation of his skills.
Describes his method of defending against bullies as 'fighting like a girl' with scratching, pulling hair, and kicking, which is resourceful but not conventionally skillful.
Engages in light, somewhat defensive banter with Agent 355 instead of seriously engaging with her self-defense lesson offer.
Shows concern for Agent 355's past relationships and tries to comfort her by acknowledging her feelings.
Acknowledges his own sadness and allows Agent 355 to comfort him, showing emotional openness.
Engages in playful sparring with Agent 355, demonstrating friendly and sincere interaction.

Shows vulnerability and sadness when discussing his missing partner Beth, but is able to move past it and engage in physical activity.
Jokes lightly about letting Agent 355 inspect the lab alone, showing casual confidence and situational awareness.
Follows Agent 355 into an uncertain and potentially dangerous location without hesitation, demonstrating bravery and readiness.
No direct action in this excerpt; mainly dialogue and interaction between Dr. Mann and Agent 355.
Enters the room casually with Ampersand on his shoulder, making a light, joking comment ('Then this is one small step for man... Etcetera, etcetera.'), despite the grim situation.
Unexpectedly lightens the atmosphere with humor and a casual demeanor in a tense, tragic moment.
Admits lack of scientific knowledge candidly and humorously, recognizing his limitations.

Does not have direct scientific knowledge but contributes important contextual information in a crisis situation.

Immediately offers to give himself up to protect Beth despite the risks to himself.
Questions the impact of his capture on the world's stability, showing a candid, sincere perspective.

Expresses surprise/disdain about the choice of escape vehicle (Yugo), showing some lack of preparedness or expectation mismatch.

Maintains awareness of the situation’s gravity as indicated by his knowing expression after Agent 355 warns him.

Whispers to Beth to let him die, saying the world is safer without him.

Asks direct questions about the status of others and the situation.

Asks for a private moment with 355 and Mann to talk with Beth, showing respect and seriousness.
Stares silently at the returned ring box, processing the breakup.
Responds nervously and listens to Beth’s honest but painful confession about breaking up to avoid hurting him.

Expresses desire to do something meaningful and help others instead of wasting time.

Wakes up quickly and alerts himself when the train starts moving, showing situational awareness.

Sits up cautiously and asks questions about his surroundings and caretaker, showing a desire to understand and connect.

Clarifies his heterosexual orientation and presents a photo of his fiancée Beth to Sonia convincingly to defuse an awkward situation.
Appears somewhat flustered and reactive during the interaction with Sonia, lacking stronger confidence or control in the social encounter.

Screams in fear and revulsion, vomits after witnessing a violent event.

Interrupts Agent 355’s emotional moment to refocus on practical matters.
Celebrates vindication about Beth's role in saving them, showing pride in his girlfriend's contribution.

Pulls Dr. Mann back inside the car after the Amazon leader collapses, showing concern and protectiveness.
